comment: Theoretically this is Ponomariov's best chance to win and get back into the race for first. But, in practice Vallejo Pons has proven tough to beat.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3
comment: Finally, someone chooses not to play c2-c4. However, 5. Bd3 is considered better by most people. Nc3 is a waiting target for ...b7-b5 or might be pinned by ...Bf8-b4. Black usually plays strongly on the dark squares, as in many Sicilian Defense variations, with White defending Nd4 & Nc3 and trying to find a way to open lines to Ke8 or make something of the half open d-file.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 b5 6. Bd3
1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 b5 6. Bd3 Bb7
comment: Taking aim at Pe4 isn't going to succeed the way it would in many other variations. Here White has taken extra precaution to keep Pe4 safe and left Nd4 a little weaker. Black should adjust his play in recognition of this.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 b5 6. Bd3 Bb7 7. O-O Nc6 8. Nxc6 Bxc6 9. Qe2
comment: preparing Nc3-d5. This is a common tactic in a variation where Black hasn't quickly developed Ng8 and Bf8 to enable ...O-O. Ke8 is definately a target!

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 b5 6. Bd3 Bb7 7. O-O Nc6 8. Nxc6 Bxc6 9. Qe2 Ne7
comment: This takes care of the immediate threat, but also leaves Black's position awkward.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 b5 6. Bd3 Bb7 7. O-O Nc6 8. Nxc6 Bxc6 9. Qe2 Ne7 10. Bd2
comment: With Bf8 blocked from action on the queen-side White decides to threaten Pb5. Bd2 prepares a2-a4.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 b5 6. Bd3 Bb7 7. O-O Nc6 8. Nxc6 Bxc6 9. Qe2 Ne7 10. Bd2 Ng6 11. a4 b4 12. Nd5
comment: Now he's combining both tactics (pressure on Pb4 and Nc3-d5) which might have the effect of overwhelming Black.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 b5 6. Bd3 Bb7 7. O-O Nc6 8. Nxc6 Bxc6 9. Qe2 Ne7 10. Bd2 Ng6 11. a4 b4 12. Nd5 a5 13. c3 b3 14. g3
comment: He's preparing Nd5-e3 and disallowing ...Ng6-f4. It's not terribly pretty, but Nd5 will have to move eventually.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 b5 6. Bd3 Bb7 7. O-O Nc6 8. Nxc6 Bxc6 9. Qe2 Ne7 10. Bd2 Ng6 11. a4 b4 12. Nd5 a5 13. c3 b3 14. g3 Bd6 15. Ne3 O-O
comment: For a position which has arisen from a Sicilian Defense this is very odd. The queen-side pawn formation is quite unusual and White's bishops on the d-file and Pg3 are peculiar. White should try to play on the d-file and perhaps try to win Pb3. He shouldn't allow Black to open the f-file with ...f7-f5. That would make Bc6 too good. So, Bd3-b5 to trade bishops might be useful. But, Pe4 needs defense, so Ne3 must move first.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 b5 6. Bd3 Bb7 7. O-O Nc6 8. Nxc6 Bxc6 9. Qe2 Ne7 10. Bd2 Ng6 11. a4 b4 12. Nd5 a5 13. c3 b3 14. g3 Bd6 15. Ne3 O-O 16. Nc4 Bc5 17. Be3 Qe7 18. Nd2
comment: White threatens Pb3 and is ready to play Bd3-b5.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 b5 6. Bd3 Bb7 7. O-O Nc6 8. Nxc6 Bxc6 9. Qe2 Ne7 10. Bd2 Ng6 11. a4 b4 12. Nd5 a5 13. c3 b3 14. g3 Bd6 15. Ne3 O-O 16. Nc4 Bc5 17. Be3 Qe7 18. Nd2 Ne5 19. Bxc5 Qxc5 20. Nxb3 Qd6 21. Bb5 f5
comment: Black tries to activate pieces in a desperate attempt to threaten Kg1, as compensation for the lost pawn.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 b5 6. Bd3 Bb7 7. O-O Nc6 8. Nxc6 Bxc6 9. Qe2 Ne7 10. Bd2 Ng6 11. a4 b4 12. Nd5 a5 13. c3 b3 14. g3 Bd6 15. Ne3 O-O 16. Nc4 Bc5 17. Be3 Qe7 18. Nd2 Ne5 19. Bxc5 Qxc5 20. Nxb3 Qd6 21. Bb5 f5 22. f4 Ng4 23. e5 Qd5 24. Bxc6
comment: Sometimes it's just that simple. White keeps the f-file closed, gets rid of Bc6 and consolidates all his advantages while letting Black have none.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Nc3 b5 6. Bd3 Bb7 7. O-O Nc6 8. Nxc6 Bxc6 9. Qe2 Ne7 10. Bd2 Ng6 11. a4 b4 12. Nd5 a5 13. c3 b3 14. g3 Bd6 15. Ne3 O-O 16. Nc4 Bc5 17. Be3 Qe7 18. Nd2 Ne5 19. Bxc5 Qxc5 20. Nxb3 Qd6 21. Bb5 f5 22. f4 Ng4 23. e5 Qd5 24. Bxc6 dxc6 25. Nd4 c5 26. Nb5 Rad8 27. h3 Nh6 28. Rfd1 Qb3 29. Rd6
comment: Black has absolutely no offense, but he does have a weak Pe6 and trapped Qb3. White threatens Ra1-a3xb3. This looked as easy as Ivanchuk's victory and is more to be expected than the struggle Kasparov had to endure before gaining the full point against Vallejo Pons. It also puts Ponomariov right back into a tie for first with Kasparov. This sets up the climactic struggle between those two in the next round -- winner take all!
